item.title: Russia-Ukraine War: Russia Targets Grain Sites in Odesa, Ukraine Says
item.description: Moscow launched drones and missiles in what Ukraine’s president said was a deliberate attack on facilities his country uses to export food.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times

item.title: Official Data Hinted at China’s Hidden Covid Toll. Then it Vanished.
item.description: Epidemiologists say a rise in cremations in an eastern province was the latest indication that the country’s official death toll from Covid is a vast undercount.
item.dc:creator: Muyi Xiao, Mara Hvistendahl and James Glanz
item.media:description: Relatives and neighbors participating in a funeral of a local woman, in a village in Zhejiang Province, China, in January.

item.title: Spain, Facing a Future of Drought, Turns to Medieval Solutions
item.description: Acequias, a network of water channels created by the Moors over 1,000 years ago, are being excavated and brought back to life to adapt to the crises of climate change.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: A group of volunteers and workers excavating “acequias” — water channels that were built hundreds of years ago — in June high up in the Sierra Nevada near Granada, in southern Spain.

item.title: Ukrainian Soldiers Fight to Reclaim Their Own Towns From Russia
item.description: Ukraine lets soldiers from towns occupied by the Russian military join the battle to reclaim them.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Private Yevheniy, standing in doorway, at a Ukrainian base in the Zaporizhzhia region.

item.title: North Korea Detains a U.S. Soldier: What to Know
item.description: The soldier, Pvt. Travis T. King, was supposed to be on a plane to the United States, but instead he joined a group tour of the DMZ. Then he bolted for the border.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers stood near the military demarcation line at Panmunjom, in February.

item.title: As Sunak Makes His Case to Britons, the Economy Could Undermine It
item.description: Britain’s Conservative government faces a morass of problems, some new, others longstanding, that are stymying Prime Minister Rishi Sunak.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak at a school in London on Monday. He has cultivated a technocratic reputation.

item.title: Kissinger Meets Top Officials in China and Gets a Warm Greeting
item.description: At 100, Henry Kissinger met with China’s top diplomat as well as its defense minister, who last month rejected an invitation to meet with the U.S. defense secretary.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, meeting Henry Kissinger, the former U.S. secretary of state, in 2019 at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing.

item.title: Thai PM Vote: Lawmakers Block Move Forward Party’s Candidate
item.description: Demonstrations unfolded as legislators prevented a progressive candidate from contesting a second parliamentary vote. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: The Thai Parliament beginning the second round of the parliamentary vote to decide the country’s next prime minister, in Bangkok on Wednesday.

item.title: How the World’s Two Largest Polluters, U.S. and China, Stack Up
item.description: From gas emissions to electric vehicles, here is how the world’s two biggest economies — and polluters — compare on taking steps to confront climate change.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: John Kerry, President Biden’s climate envoy, meeting with Premier Li Qiang of China in Beijing on Wednesday.

item.title: Xi Rejects Pressure on China to Do More to Address Climate Change
item.description: The speech by China’s leader, Xi Jinping, to Chinese officials came as John Kerry, President Biden’s climate envoy, urged Beijing to move more quickly to address global warming.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Chris Buckley
item.media:description: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, visiting a coal yard of a company in northwestern China’s Shanxi Province last year.

item.title: Extreme Heat Grips 3 Continents as Climate Change Warms Earth
item.description: Across North America, Europe and Asia, hundreds of millions of people endured blistering conditions. The U.S. special envoy for climate change called it “a threat to all of humankind.”
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: A helicopter crew fights fires in Mandra, Greece, west of Athens, on Tuesday.

item.title: Yiddish Is Alive and Well in Melbourne, Australia
item.description: Australia has the largest proportion of Holocaust survivors of any country besides Israel. In Melbourne, some of their descendants are leading the way to preserve the Yiddish language.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Christina Simons for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kindergarten students learning Yiddish at Sholem Aleichem College in Melbourne, Australia.

item.title: Modi and India’s Diaspora: A Complex Love Affair Making Global Waves
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi has tried to fuse his image to the economic and political power of Indians abroad. They voice both pride and worry in return.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India at a rally in an arena in Sydney, in May.

item.title: Mandela Goes From Hero to Scapegoat as South Africa Struggles
item.description: Nelson Mandela is revered worldwide and celebrated on July 18, his birthday. But at home, a younger generation is disillusioned with the country, his party and the anti-apartheid leader, too.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Gulshan Khan
item.media:credit: Gulshan Khan for The New York Times
item.media:description: South Africa’s s largest monument to Nelson Mandela: a 30-foot bronze statue in Pretoria, South Africa’s executive capital.

item.title: Ghibli Park Celebrates “Totoro” And Other Miyazaki Movies
item.description: The Japanese company Studio Ghibli opened a theme park to celebrate the eccentric, charming animated movies of its founder, Hayao Miyazaki. Could two ‘Totoro’-loving toddlers find happiness there?
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:credit: Andrew Faulk for The New York Times
item.media:description: A made-for-Instagram tableau at Ghibli Park in Japan, inspired by the Studio Ghibli film “Arietty.”

item.title: Read Your Way Through Salvador
item.description: The writer Itamar Vieira Junior says that to “feel the intensity of life on the streets of Salvador” in Bahia, Brazil, a reader must start with Jorge Amado.
item.dc:creator: Itamar Vieira Junior and translated by Johnny Lorenz

item.title: U.K. Inflation Rate Slows to 7.9 Percent
item.description: The larger-than-expected slowdown, led by motor vehicle fuel prices, offers some relief to the government and the Bank of England.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Sam Bush for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Quayside in Canary Wharf, a purpose-built financial district in London.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Extreme heat across the world.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A helicopter crew fights fires in Mandra, Greece, west of Athens, on Tuesday.

item.title: Russia Bombards Ukraine Port After Bridge Attack and Grain Deal Collapse
item.description: Russian forces launched a barrage of missiles and drones at Odesa, not usually a major target, a day after important shifts in the conduct of the war.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Ivan Nechepurenko and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A Russian military ship near Kerch, Crimea, on Monday. Russia accused Ukraine of damaging the 12-mile bridge between Crimea and Russia on Monday; Ukraine did not claim responsibility.

item.title: U.N. Officials Urge Regulation of AI at Security Council Meeting
item.description: Security Council members said they feared that a new technology might prove a major threat to world peace.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Jack Clark, an A.I. expert, addressing the U.N. Security Council via video link on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Blacklists Two Spyware Firms Run by an Israeli Former General
item.description: The moves by the Commerce Department against the Europe-based firms are the latest effort to rein in a spyware industry that has spiraled out of control in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti
item.media:description: Tal Dilian, a former general in Israeli military intelligence, controls the two firms blacklisted by the Commerce Department.

item.title: The U.S. Announces $750 Million in Aid for Ukraine
item.description: The new funds will go toward food assistance, health and hygienic care, and providing emergency shelter, the agency said.
item.dc:creator: Gabriela Sá Pessoa
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.media:description: Samantha Power, the USAID administrator, speaking in Odesa, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Legacy of Boris Johnson Looms Over By-election to Replace Him
item.description: The vote to pick a new member of Parliament in the ex-prime minister’s once-reliably Conservative district is just one of three by-elections on Thursday that will give a snapshot of Britain’s mood.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Boris Johnson visiting a care home in Uxbridge, England, the area he represented in Parliament, in May 2022, when he was prime minister.

item.title: Australian Man and His Dog Rescued After Nearly 3 Months at Sea
item.description: “I have not had food, enough food, for a long time,” Tim Shaddock, 54, said after he and his dog, Bella, were found floating aboard a catamaran, 1,200 miles from land in the Pacific Ocean.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Timothy Shaddock and his dog, Bella, after their rescue by the Mexican tuna trawler Maria Delia.

item.title: Patrick Zaki, Student and Rights Advocate, Is Jailed by Egypt
item.description: The case of Patrick Zaki, who had been studying in Italy and was convicted of spreading “fake news,” prompted an outpouring of support in two countries.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Patrick Zaki arriving for a trial hearing in Mansoura, Egypt, in June 2022.

item.title: Putin Will Not Attend BRICS Summit, South Africa’s President Says
item.description: The decision allows South Africa to avoid the predicament of whether to arrest the Russian leader, who is the subject of an international warrant, if he traveled to Johannesburg for a BRICS meeting.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, right, with President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa at the BRICS summit meeting in Brasília in 2019.

item.title: King Charles III Earned Record Income from Rental Properties
item.description: Rents are rising across Britain, and the nation’s most famous landlord was no exception. He received about $34 million from his real estate portfolio.
item.dc:creator: Jane Bradley
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: King Charles and Queen Camilla on the balcony at Buckingham Palace on the day of the king’s coronation, in May.

item.title: Cerberus or Caronte? Why Europe Is Starting to Name Heat Waves
item.description: The World Meteorological Organization has warned against naming heat wave events and said it has no plans to do so, despite calls by some experts who say names could raise awareness about heat’s dangers.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Francesca Volpi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Trying to cool off in Florence, Italy, on Thursday.

item.title: Protests Meet Bibby Stockholm, U.K. Barge for Asylum Seekers
item.description: Some of those protesting the Bibby Stockholm’s arrival in southern England wanted better treatment for refugees. Others opposed bringing migrants to the area. None wanted the barge.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Ben Birchall/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A barge called the Bibby Stockholm is supposed to receive up to 500 asylum seekers. It arrived at the port of Portland, in southern England, on Tuesday.

item.title: Heat Divide Leaves Low-Income Workers Among the Most Vulnerable
item.description: Europe’s latest heat wave has highlighted the inequities between those who can afford to shelter from the heat and those who can’t.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Camilla Ferrari for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cyclist making a delivery in Milan on Tuesday. Southern Europe has been under a heat wave.

item.title: Thailand’s Prime Minister Vote Puts Coalition at Risk
item.description: The progressive Move Forward Party has failed to form a government, leaving members of the liberal opposition scrambling to find alternatives.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and Ryn Jirenuwat
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Pita Limjaroenrat, center, leader of Move Forward Party and candidate for prime minister, speaking to the media after a meeting with his coalition, in Bangkok, on Monday.

item.title: The Economic Fallout From Extreme Heat Will Rise Over Time
item.description: Among the costs of very high temperatures: reduced labor productivity, damaged crops, higher mortality rates, trade disruption and dampened investment.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:description: A construction worker in Seville, Spain, on Sunday. Researchers have found that extreme temperatures can create negative economic impacts, including reduced labor productivity.

item.title: As Heat Waves Descend on Europe, So Do Tourists
item.description: Soaring temperatures have gripped the continent during one of its most popular travel seasons.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Camilla Ferrari for The New York Times
item.media:description: A long line for gelato near the Duomo in Milan on Monday.

item.title: Greece Wildfires Force Thousands to Flee
item.description: Thousands of acres have burned, leaving residents and firefighters scrambling.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Smoke rising from a wildfire in the Lagonisi area of Attica, Greece, on Monday.

item.title: Moscow Warns Ukraine Against Shipping Grain Across the Black Sea Without Its Consent
item.description: The Kremlin’s comments came after Ukraine’s leader called for the shipments to continue despite Russia’s withdrawal from a landmark grain deal.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cargo vessel being filled with grain in the Black Sea port of Pivdennyi, Ukraine, last August.

item.title: U.S. Nuclear-Capable Sub Visits South Korea
item.description: The submarine made a port call as part of Washington’s effort to show its commitment to defending its East Asian ally.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: In this image released by U.S. Strategic Command, the submarine Kentucky is transiting the Hood Canal in 2017.

item.title: North Korea Detains U.S. Soldier After Unauthorized Border Crossing
item.description: The service member is the first known American to be held in North Korean custody since​ Bruce Byron Lowrance​ was detained for a month after illegally entering the country from China in 2018.​
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun, Michael D. Shear, John Ismay and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Unauthorized crossings through Panmunjom, on the border between North and South Korea, are highly unusual.

item.title: As China Bakes in Record Heat, John Kerry Presses Beijing on Climate Change
item.description: The extreme heat wave choking China has become a talking point for John Kerry, President Biden’s climate envoy, in his meetings with officials in Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Lisa Friedman
item.category: Great Hall of the People (Beijing, China)
item.media:description: “You and I know things are changing,” Mr. Kerry said as he met with Premier Li Qiang of China in Beijing.

item.title: Spanish Vote Threatens Efforts to Recover Franco’s Victims
item.description: Spain’s left-wing government has tried to accelerate exhumations of mass graves left from the dictatorship. If it wins Sunday’s election, the right may end that.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Samuel Aranda
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Descendants of victims of Franco’s firing squads at the cemetery in Paterna, Spain, where 2,200 people were executed.

item.title: Herzog of Israel Meets With Biden Amid U.S. Unease With Netanyahu
item.description: President Biden sought a middle ground in meeting with President Isaac Herzog of Israel, amid Republican criticism and divisions within his own party over a key American ally.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: President Isaac Herzog of Israel met with President Biden at the White House on Tuesday. He plans to address a joint session of Congress on Wednesday.

item.title: Israelis Protest Against Judicial Overhaul
item.description: Tens of thousands of Israelis blocked roads and demonstrated over Benjamin Netanyahu’s plans to limit the power of the judiciary.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: A protest in Tel Aviv on Tuesday against the government’s judicial overhaul plan.

item.title: Victoria, Australia, Backs Out as Host of 2026 Commonwealth Games
item.description: The state of Victoria cited budget issues in deciding not to stage the multisports competition, originally known as the British Empire Games, raising questions about the event’s fading prestige.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Thawing relations between Israel and the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu chairs a cabinet meeting in Jerusalem on Monday.

item.title: A Current War Collides With the Past: Remnants of World War II in Ukraine
item.description: World War II has been an ideological battlefield in today’s war in Ukraine, and it is cropping up on the actual battlefield as well.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oleksandr Shkalikov, a Ukrainian tank driver, scrambles over the surreal landscape revealed after the Kakhovka dam was destroyed.

item.title: Explosions Damage Crimea Bridge as Russia Blames Ukraine for Attack
item.description: Russia accused Ukraine of hitting the Kerch Strait Bridge for the second time in 10 months, saying that two maritime drones had struck the bridge, an essential supply line for Russian troops.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora, Neil MacFarquhar and Haley Willis
item.media:credit: Crimea24TV, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A still from a video released by a Crimean news station showing a damaged section of the Kerch Strait Bridge on Monday.

item.title: More Than 50 Whales Die After Being Stranded in Scotland
item.description: Only one pilot whale survived out of the 55 beached on the Isle of Lewis in northwest Scotland on Sunday. It was the largest mass stranding in the region in over a decade.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che
item.media:credit: Cristina McAvoy/British Divers Marine Life Rescue
item.media:description: More than 50 pilot whales died on Sunday after being stranded on a beach in Scotland.

item.title: Russia Stops Ukraine Grain Deal, Shaking World Food Markets
item.description: Moscow, which has repeatedly complained that the U.N.-brokered agreement is one-sided in Ukraine’s favor, said it could return to the deal if its demands were met.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Ivan Nechepurenko, Liz Alderman and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: SWIFT (Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication)
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukraine is a major exporter of foodstuffs, and Africa, in particular, relies on grain stored in silos like these, in Marianske, in the southern Dnipro region, in June.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: China Engages as Its Economy Sputters
item.description: Also, an attack on a bridge between Russia and Crimea.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A market in Suzhou, China, in April.

item.title: In a Bid to Curb Migrants, Europe Strikes a Deal With Tunisia
item.description: After the deadliest shipwreck in years in the Mediterranean, E.U. officials will pay Tunisia to prevent migrants from setting to sea.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Migrants from sub-Saharan African, who said they had been abandoned in the desert by the Tunisian authorities, arriving at a shelter in Libya on Sunday.

item.title: Mystery Object Is Found on Remote Beach in Western Australia
item.description: The authorities said the cylindrical object, which was found about 155 miles north of Perth, did not pose a risk to the public, but they have yet to identify it.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: A metal cylinder that was found on a beach in Western Australia is at least two meters, or about 6 feet 6 inches, tall, according to local news reports.

item.title: Biden Invites Netanyahu to United States, Easing Tensions
item.description: The invitation to the Israeli prime minister came on the eve of a visit to the White House by Isaac Herzog, the Israeli president.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: President Isaac Herzog of Israel and President Biden during a meeting in the Oval Office in October. Mr. Herzog is visiting Washington again this week.

item.title: Wagner Convoy Arrives at Camp in Belarus
item.description: The troop movements are the private company’s biggest — and most public — showing since its failed rebellion in Russia last month.
item.dc:creator: Christoph Koettl and Christiaan Triebert

item.title: Iran Steps Up Policing of Women Who Defy Strict Dress Code
item.description: The country’s morality police disappeared from the streets late last year as the authorities tried to calm anti-government protests. Now, patrols are once again watching for violators.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Leily Nikounazar
item.media:description: Iranian police officers patrolling the streets of the capital, Tehran, on Sunday. It was unclear whether the authorities were again deploying the morality police, or were requiring the regular police to take on that role.

item.title: What We Know About the Crimea Bridge Attack
item.description: Monday’s strike was the second in less than a year to target the Kerch Strait Bridge, which holds strategic and symbolic importance for Russia.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

item.title: Where Is Qin Gang, China’s Foreign Minister? Beijing Won’t Say.
item.description: Qin Gang has not made a public appearance in three weeks. The Communist Party’s habitual secrecy around top officials has fueled speculation over the reasons for his absence.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and David Pierson
item.media:credit: Leah Millis/Agence France-Presse Via Getty Images
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Qin Gang of China, right, with Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken in Beijing last month. Mr. Qin’s last reported engagements were on June 25.

item.title: Wildfire in Canary Islands Forces Thousands to Evacuate
item.description: The blaze on the island of La Palma has driven some 4,000 residents from their homes and burned about 10,000 acres. Wildfires also broke out in Greece.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A wildfire that started Saturday on La Palma in the Canary Islands left a stand of charred trees on Monday, as more than 500 firefighters sought to bring it under control.
